Madam President, Commissioner, anyone visiting sub-Saharan Africa readily recognizes in the realities of the countries the enormous weakness of their health systems and the extremely negative impact this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations those services should serve.
The internationally disseminated indicators consistently confirm this.
It is profoundly unsettling to consider that simple gestures and practices, not even particularly elaborate or expensive, could be sufficient to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard, and we must always bear in mind how cooperation in the field of health is truly strategic and directly impacts not only one of the Millennium Development Goals, but many of them.

The Court of Accounts found that community funding for the health sector has not increased since 2000 in proportion to its total development aid, despite commitments made by the Commission regarding the Millennium Development Goals and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa.
end of quotation

And it recognized that, once again, the commission contributed significantly, through its funding, to establishing the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but did not grant the same attention to strengthening health themes that was expected to be one of its priorities.
end of quotation.

end of quotation

Optimizing the way assistance is provided, bearing in mind the seemingly antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity to beneficiary populations, is to deliver a service that can save many lives.

Thank you, Mr. President, thank you, Mr. Commissioner. Above all, I want to reinforce the importance of this issue raised by Deputy Golarantes, because it is a matter of greater food justice.

We are all perfectly aware that in a situation of an acute influenza pandemic, the Southern countries suffered most from this problem and from the consequences of the virus's proliferation, not the Northern countries.

And each year, we witness with complete passivity the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have either been eradicated or are being treated in northern countries – a vast list: malaria, dengue fever, yellow fever, tuberculosis.
We have no limits for this list, and we passively witness this problem.

We effectively use the countries of the Global South as providers of free data, samples, and new viral strains so that we can improve treatment in the countries of the Global North, but, nonetheless, we remain without an effective response to these problems. And therefore, regarding the issues that were raised, I would only like to add a few more.
We want, effectively, to treat this problem as a public health issue or as a business.
Because, if it is treated as a public health problem, we must guarantee equal access to treatment in all regions of the world, and to achieve this, efforts must be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask, and I hope it is not the case, whether we are expecting the vaccination campaigns in Europe to become so overwhelmed.
The secondary effects reveal themselves to be so negative in this plan, to the point where it constitutes an act of generosity, and suddenly we begin to send necessary vaccines to southern countries.

Finally, I simply wanted to ask whether the European Union, we Europeans, and the Commission feel comfortable with a system or a model where countries in the North address pandemics through a model of prevention and countries in the South do so with palliative measures or merely with leftovers.

This new microfinance instrument will enable the provision of microcredit to small businesses and to individuals who have lost their employment and wish to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important at a time when the economic crisis is expected to result in the loss of three and a half million jobs in the European Union alone.

As a consequence of economic austerity, banks have ceased to grant loans for job creation and business development, and access to credit has become more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.

Alternatively, this new form of microfinancing will counteract the current trend of restricted access to credit, facilitating the acquisition of funds necessary for the launch of new businesses and new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reallocate €100 million from the Progress programme budget to this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The economic financial crisis is equally a social crisis.
Thus, reallocating resources from progress aimed at the most vulnerable groups is not entirely the most suitable solution.
For this reason, I support the creation of a separate budget line to finance this instrument, as well as an increase in the allocation to 150 million euros.

We also agree with the need to clarify in the legislation itself that Group Avo are the vulnerable groups who have difficulty entering or returning to the labor market and who face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, the reference to specific groups should be suppressed.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential for people to have financial support and also adequate information. Many thanks.

Mr. President, given the urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen were several steps backward.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than others, but there was also a desire for more divisions. As a result, what happened was that we entered a situation of each country for itself, where each state could define its own targets and, moreover, under a voluntary regime.
It must be reiterated that having a two-degree Celsius target, or targets for funding, without any clarification, cannot serve as consolation either.
Therefore, what I believe is that we must act in terms of the future, and acting in terms of the future means moving beyond rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always stated so.
But, when we arrived in Copenhagen, it turned out not to define, nor defend the goals it had previously affirmed to be its goals and from which it would not deviate.

Therefore, what I ask is whether, for the future, we will not be more just if we cease to allow those who are poorest to continue paying the highest price, at the cost of this failure and the decisions of some over others.

A plan by the government has come to light to control newspapers, television stations, and radio stations, which calls into question freedom of expression.
This week, a well-known journalist, Mário Crespo, had an opinion piece censored, also at the suggestion or apparent suggestion of the Prime Minister.

This report concerning the European Regional Development Fund aims to broaden the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector to benefit marginalized communities within our Member States.
To date, this support has applied only to marginalized communities residing in the urban areas of the new Member States.
In other words, since the vast majority of these types of communities live in rural areas and in makeshift shelters, they could not benefit from support for replacing substandard housing.
It fundamentally concerns how to combat a vaccine and give Member States and their regions greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.
I also welcome equal treatment for all Member States, as marginalized communities with needs for support and integration deserve our concern, regardless of the Member State to which they belong.

Upon concluding, in a first reading, this important report in the fight against poverty and for human dignity, its rapid application within the economic budget plan can also be achieved, responding effectively to the crisis that affects us.

Tomorrow, we will implement modifications to regulation F which assume particular importance for the so-called former Member States and also for Portugal.

These changes will allow for extending the use of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) in the housing sector in favor of marginalized communities, as currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development operations.

The alterations I proposed, together with other colleagues and which were approved by a large majority in the Regional Development Committee, will allow former Member States and not just the new ones, as stipulated in the original proposal, to also benefit from this financing possibility.

With this, I attempted to prevent the establishment of a precedent that I consider dangerous and that would exclude all former Member States from this, and likely from other, additional uses of Community assistance.
What would make no sense at all, since housing-related issues, particularly among marginalized communities, exist in both new and old Member States.
I wish to reiterate that the antiquity of the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds and that this criterion should be abandoned without delay.

Commissioner and Council, we are here to discuss the reinvention of the energy system at the European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.

Failures in energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear power, biofuels, and solar energy are discussed, and even energy efficiency is mentioned as a more cost-effective way to reduce emissions.

When asked where the money is going, they say it comes from the commission stemming from where he is.
I confess that I am no more enlightened by being told that the money will come from where it is, without it being specified exactly where it is.

Therefore, this investment in public or private partnerships, which is systematically made when we discuss AI and carbon technologies, leaves us with a certainty: not knowing where the money comes from and knowing that these are public or private partnerships, we know who will be paying.

Without this clarification, it appears to me that, once again, we are systematically passing the bill for the energy model transition on to future generations.

President, the European Union recently celebrated, within the framework of the World Trade Organization, an agreement with the countries of Latin America, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce tariffs on banana and plantain imports.

We draw your attention to the fact that such an agreement will have a directly negative effect on European banana producers, particularly on wood-derived banana products in Portugal, but also in an even more intense manner on the Canary Islands in Spain.

I recall that the situation of producers in these regions is already seriously hampered by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and by the size of their holdings, which leads them to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

It is therefore urgent to take measures in defense of the banana producers of Madeira and the Canary Islands, taking into account the grave and immediate impact that the new Geneva agreement has on the European market for imports and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas originating from these outermost regions.

European citizens' frustration is immense. The financial system that should have served them destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment plans, their jobs, and, in short, their future.
Regarding the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market—banks, insurance, securities—the path forward is clear and lies in the architecture that we are discussing here today.
We need, in fact, a robust European supervisory architecture that covers all products of actors, endowed with methodologies and instruments of
effective interventions that are capable of responding to the reality of the market, which, particularly in the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and that prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose bursting affects the entire system and spreads to the real economy.

But if, despite these safeguards, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms that limit contagion, particularly with regard to the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the repository of citizens' savings.

Here, precisely in the powers and competencies of banking supervisory authority, lies the capacity to implement a new strategy regarding the management of cross-border banking crises, a topic to which my report refers.
It is not within our power to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation are carried out
In an orderly manner, limiting the collateral effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from bearing the costs of the crises they generate.

To that end, a set of new instruments is necessary. It is necessary to adopt rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments, and terminology common to all stakeholders in restructuring, reorganization, or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, notably bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to grant supervisors extended powers of intervention.
It is necessary to define clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow interventions to be initiated in an institution facing difficulties.
Contingency plans must be prepared.
This entire process for twenty-seven member states requires time.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is unacceptable and, as such, is highly responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events and floods, or even for the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
Floral loss places all of humanity at risk, but this risk and impact are not shared equally among us.
Communities with fewer resources and those most dependent on the forest and nature for survival are the most affected.
Deforestation pertains to our collective existence, the depletion of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and indigenous communities, and social justice.
The primary cause of deforestation is the illegal exploitation of timber, which accounts for 20% to 40% of global industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also discussing the transfer of wealth from timber-producing countries to those consuming that same wood.
This illegal practice jeopardizes the sustainable exploitation of wood and the companies that engage in it.
Fine words are not enough.
This Parliament should adopt firm measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in that direction by defining the prohibition of timber trade.
Good intentions are not enough, either.
Means and resources are required, notably sanctions that, in this case, may be of three types.

First, that the economic benefit from aggravated illegal practices be withdrawn, in fact; second, the confiscation of the wood and products in question; and third, the immediate suspension of the authorization to exercise a commercial activity.

And so it is because whoever exploits or commercializes a natural resource must be socially responsible. And so it is also that whoever places wood or wood products into the European Union for the first time must be subject to due diligence to ensure that it is wood exploited legally.
It is for this reason that all subsequent operators must provide basic information about this wood, namely its provenance and its destination.
The population must also have the right, and here I conclude, Mr. President, the right to access information about who complies and who does not. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, I wanted to begin by congratulating colleagues Luan and Manesco on the remarkable work they have done in their respective reports.
Both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion concerning the new cohesion policy for the 2014/2020 programming period.
Today, more than ever, the realization of economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for affirming the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that, by reinforcing and developing the regional dimension, we can have a cohesive Europe internally and a competitive Europe externally.

In this regard, I would highlight three points that I consider pivotal. Firstly, decentralization, ensuring that local and regional authorities, particularly those holding legislative powers, participate more and contribute to a better implementation of the cohesion policy.

Member states are to invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of Structural Funds on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives, and finally, the strengthening of the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management, and implementation of programs.
only in this way, with the greatest involvement of these authorities throughout the entire process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

The primary concern regarding the subordination to the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us then do not just this, but also make your life easier, avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that deter your participation.
Thus, we will be able to achieve the objective of genuine territorial cohesion.
Thus, we will see reduced disparities within the European Union, currently markedly contrasting and with a significant disparity between rich and poor regions.
Greater participation also means greater responsibility, and this responsibility must be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better in order to have a stronger and more competitive Europe.

Mr. Rang has a minute and a half, Mr. President. The first point I wanted to make clear here, and which it’s important to reinforce in this Parliament, is that
That, contrary to what sometimes appears in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been fundamental in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in an extremely difficult situation, with the currencies of the more fragile countries experiencing enormous devaluation, and with the eventual German Mark appreciating to an impossible level, unable to sustain the German economy and the European economy.
Therefore, the euro has been a factor of stability, especially not only for countries within the euro area, but also for the currencies of countries that chose not to join the euro area.

And precisely because we need to defend this community that managed to respond to the crisis in no other way, and as we will see, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro has, in fact, advantages.

We now have the responsibility within this Council to do everything to defend the euro, specifically to establish a stabilization fund, which follows a community method and is capable of introducing responsibility in countries.

agriculture requires the involvement of other areas, such as those pertaining to internal market competition and financial regulation, as well as others that also require their treatment on other extra-community stages, such as the G20 and the WTO.

We will await the result of the vote, but we know, Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral comfort.

We hope for concrete and appropriate actions. I sincerely hope, Mr. Commissioner, that you will put them into practice and that the commission, which has the initiative that, unfortunately, this Parliament does not, will put them into practice.

It is precisely this priority that granting this domain affords, transforming legislative initiative so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and are treated with equality and the dignity they deserve. Thank you.

Mr. President, I believe that these two countries, like others in this region, show us how, in recent years, European leaders have sometimes prioritized business over democracy, and the side of dictators over the side of the poor.
I am frankly concerned about the situation currently unfolding in Egypt and today’s developments, and it is for this reason that I believe we should not have complacency, but rather solidarity.
Solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens who are in Cairo and throughout the country, fed up with hunger, fed up with oppression, fed up with unemployment.

And that is why, following today's speech by Mubarak, following the release of the regime's enforcers, following the creation of a clear and unobstructed path to violence, we must say that we must stand alongside these people.
We cannot allow a strategy of fear to be created so that they return home.
Having been in Portugal for 36 years, we would have returned home if we had heeded this advice.
And indeed, we returned, because that is how we achieved a democratic revolution.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I would also like to say that I believe this issue is important insofar as we continue to live in the deception we have lived in within Europe.
Deception is a false promise, as I want to call it, because we have been operating, particularly in the matter of collecting terminal cells, nuclear cord blood, based on misleading information.
We know, and it has been mentioned, that in Europe, collecting stem cells from the umbilical cord is not sufficient.

And yet, we also know that its possibilities for treating diseases can be inexhaustible, diseases such as those previously mentioned concerning cancer, Alzheimer's disease, and rare diseases—the possibilities are immense.

But what we allowed to happen was the establishment of a set of private cell preservation banks, telling parents that they could store their children’s cells and, from that point onward, at the time of birth and from that point onward, cure them in the future if necessary.
I believe we should be more responsible than that, because the probability of ensuring that happens is very low, as we know.
And this false promise that is sold to parents costs money.
In Portugal, for example, this false premise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly involves creating public banks, stem cell banks, because only with public banks could we guarantee equal utilization, equal access.
It is an effective medical treatment and further research that should be equal for all, and not merely utilize stem cells as commodities or a burgeoning business—one that benefits only a few.
Therefore, I believe solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are not, in the end, things that can be considered excessive requirements.
We do not have the power to impose, we have the power to promote.
This falls within our purview, and I believe we should do it in the name of equality. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. The price of food has reached a historical high, marking the seventh consecutive increase.
Several factors can explain this increase, with the first being a short-term factor.
It relates to the coincidence of excessive climatic conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina.
But there are two factors that are structuring in nature, of a structuring order, and that is why I bring these two factors up here.
The first relates to the fact that some producers and consumers of foods that were exporters have become importers, as is the case with China.
This has nothing to do with the fact that the weight of certain large multinationals can secure favorable rulings on pricing.
The example of cereals is this very clear level, it is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation therefore places farmers in immense uncertainty regarding food prices.
Europe must, therefore, return to doing what it ceased to do some time ago, namely, protecting its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone seeks forms of protection and where multinational corporations manipulate prices, we cannot continue without gender, thank you very much.

The gravity of the moment does not stem from the fact that the zone and Europe as a whole have a deficit or excessive external debt. Rather, it stems from the fact that the economies comprising it persistently and gravely diverge under the impact of the common policy.

Mr. President, Commissioner, this is a good report from my colleague from home.
Firstly, it is necessary to ask why review VAT in the European Union?
First, the need to harmonize with the single market.
The more regimes and varieties of VAT, the less fluid the market will be.
A reform of the VAT favors e-commerce, centers competition on the value of goods and the base price of goods and services, and not on fiscal differences.
Combats fraud and guarantees the trust so essential, especially in cross-border transactions. Improves the economics of PMs and reduces administrative burdens.

First, a straightforward, clear, and transparent digital support mechanism tailored to the needs of the single market.
Measure five, concerning services, the need to review legislation on standardization and the implementation of the directive.
The new measure, aimed at removing fiscal obstacles and explicitly reviewing the VAT system and VAT equalization in online and face-to-face commerce, which we all experience when ordering books.
The pressures for VAT reform stem from two fundamental orders of reasons.
First, the economic crisis.
More revenue measures are needed, likely including, in some countries, a reduction in contributions on labor to promote economic development, shifting that burden to VAT.
Firstly, a second major source of pressure is population aging, demographic aging, and the trend of shifting from indirect to direct taxes, which is due to the reduction in the tax base.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the variation range in the standard VAT rate so that we can all better understand.
Greater transparency is needed in the definition of the reduced VAT rate and its scope of application, along with a clear and widely publicized list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study loopholes for tax exemptions, knowing well that each exemption brings with it a retinue of small or large frauds.
Finally, to welcome the recent proposal from the commission to create a European VAT.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly well known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of Member States hinder competitiveness.
The dichotomy, the quality of prices, and the complexity of laws and procedures are evident.
It is essential to examine existing best practices, particularly in Portugal, where electronic procurement has functioned effectively and has facilitated public contracting.
An effective European public procurement represents the preferred means of controlling the public deficit and fostering greater growth.

To achieve this, it is necessary to have a legal framework, stable and predictable, with less bureaucratic procedures to attract Private Management Societies and to defend social and environmental values.

It is therefore that I express satisfaction with the intentions presented to us by the Commissioner Barnier here for the revision of public procurement, as well as with its inclusion this year as one of the twelve priorities of the Single Market Act.

, unfortunately, the objectives proposed by the European Union and 50 of the judgments by electronic procedure in 2010 failed, being found in the average values of five hundred cases.
Only a few countries, such as my own Portugal, have succeeded in this area.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are overwhelmingly evident and have been outlined here. It allows for the replacement of costly access procedures with simple consultation of the electronic platform, that is, it significantly reduces costs for companies, particularly for the

Small and medium-sized enterprises, the dissemination of information via the internet and the ease of accessing procedural documents broaden the number of suppliers, increasing competition and enabling more advantageous procurement, thereby transforming the contract award process for public contracts.

Easier and more flexible access simplifies the process of accessing European Union public contracts, particularly for small businesses, thereby facilitating participation in the market of public contracts – these vital engines of the economy.
In this regard, we welcome and encourage the European Commission for strengthening the mechanisms to transform electronic public procurement into an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you.

to the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the rapporteurs of the partners from the four committees involved. These partners are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 commitments, all of which were approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest aroused by this topic of new skills and jobs.
It is ultimately a matter of preparing Europe’s human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the coming decade.
The key strategy for drafting the report was to reformulate common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the report's coherence.
I believe that objective was achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the vulnerabilities of the European economic and social model, as well as nullified many of the advances achieved in the past.
Since the initial effects of the crisis began to be felt in labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than five million jobs.
Today, nearly twenty-three million people are employed.
Youth unemployment is even more alarming. The youth unemployment rate is nearing 21% and represents more than double the general unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States, unemployment rates vary with levels of qualifications.
This means that people with higher qualifications find employment more easily.
We also know that, in the near future, the needs regarding aptitudes, skills, and qualifications will increase across all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges: first, job creation; second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
Subsequently, the sustainability of social security systems and, finally, the difficulty in finding people with the appropriate skills to fill job openings.
This report, therefore, has a dual objective: first, to underscore the need for rapid action to address skills gaps in Europe; second, to better anticipate the labor market's needs regarding skills.

To this end, several measures are highlighted. First, to ensure the availability of qualified labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science and innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I mentioned previously, skills needs should be identified early, within a timeframe of at least ten years.
Do you know today the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications?
Subsequently, participation in lifelong learning and professional requalification should be increased, as should the reduction of school dropout rates.
Another important matter is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications, and the urgency of progressing with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the connection that should exist between educational institutions and the needs of the labor market.
Internships should be of high quality and supervised by tutors in order to lead to employment and eliminate any potential abuse of the interns’ situation.
Particular emphasis is also given to the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote demand and job creation.
We have the future ahead of us, and we must create employment.
Small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in this objective.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers and, consequently, the need for coordination of social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, particularly the portability of pensions.

Finally, the issue of labor market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labor market, the rules of flexibility and security should be adapted to the socioeconomic contexts of each Member State. Many thanks.

Eight thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the maritime policy defends a coordinated approach to the management and governance of the oceans, seas, and coasts from a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

A global perspective and an integrated approach imply the interaction of European maritime policies and call for improved governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past years through various funded initiatives concerning preparatory actions and pilot projects.
Integrated maritime policy should therefore continue to benefit from adequate funding during the coming years of the current financial programming period.
In this regard, I advocate for adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects and support funded by a stable framework concerning the objectives of this program.

Issues of policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics of particular interest to certain regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

Eruption regions, with the exception of the French war, being volatile and of small size, depend on a limited number of economic activities and in which activities related to the sea and fishing assume particular importance.
Furthermore, ultraperipheral regions contribute to the European Union having the world’s largest exclusive economic zone.

The Groups P represent more than half of the European Union’s exclusive economic zone, approximately 15 out of 25 million square kilometers, and, together with coastal regions, are fundamental to the economic growth of the European Union and its Member States.
A program such as integrated maritime policy’s constant should benefit these regions, prioritizing transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework beginning in 2014.
To fail to seize the opportunity when discussing integrated maritime policy to underscore the enormous potential that the Atlantic dimension and its embrace hold for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime frontier of Europe, also establishes its connection to North and South America and to Africa, conferring a strategic dimension for Europe indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy designed with an eye to the future.

And it is with a view to the future that integrated maritime policy, beyond promoting the coordination of maritime activities, should place the potential of the Atlantic, in its three-dimensional dimension, at the forefront of its priorities, based on science and technology.

Research into the deep-sea environment of the Central Atlantic Mid-Ocean Ridge and the seafloor constitutes a new frontier with potential in biotechnology and mineral resources, and is of immeasurable value to the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore leverage the privileged position of steels and the influence of its department of graphics to be installed in the observatory of the Deep Mark. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is incorrect, the medications do not work.
In the case of the Eurozone, excessive remedies have brought it to the brink of death.
The seemingly miraculous solutions that were proposed were also discredited by the markets.
The Finiro Stabilization Fund, successive tranches of the Stability and Growth Pact, and the Troika’s revenues in countries under the program.
The blind discipline without growth, vowed a recessive wave and among fully interconnected economies, which, consequently, were contaminated by bankruptcies and unemployment.
At the hands of the markets—that is, the rating agencies and speculators—governments are falling one after another, and solvent countries are being transformed into insolvent ones.

Altering treaties is now another step on this disastrous trajectory, with an aggravating factor. We risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty, placing countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to alter the treaties.
It is necessary, in this emergency in which we find ourselves, to make two decisions.
First, it is necessary to establish a genuine agenda for sustained growth and cohesion.
Where is the 2020 agenda?
Where is the relaunch budget?
Where are those so-called projects, the projects suitable for Europe’s structural investments?
Secondly, it is necessary to safeguard sovereign debt.
Naturally, eurobonds are necessary, but in this emergency in which we find ourselves, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defend sovereign debt against speculators.
Not in a hesitant manner, but with a definitive stance as befits any central bank that defends its currency and the economy it supports.
For this, it is not necessary to change the treaties; what is required is political will and European conviction.

We will move the treaty when we have extracted all the lessons from the present crisis, and there are quite a few lessons to be learned. However, this is certainly not the moment. Thank you very much.
Mr. President and Commissioner Dali, the first forum of the single market, an idea stemming from the Greco report, took place in Kraków.
It was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish presidency with European, national, regional, and local authorities, and civil society.

The law needs to be transposed and how the strategy of other e38 priorities identified in the act will be applied to the single market.
For a market to exist, trust is necessary.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be taken for granted; it must be stimulated, nurtured.

Thank you, Mr. President, I believe we are at a juncture to assess the impact of these crisis policies and austerity measures that have affected so many countries, as well as the so-called structural reforms.
And it is within this context that I believe we cannot fail to see how they have generated so much social commission.
And it has generated social unrest not only in countries facing the greatest difficulties, in developing countries, not only in the so-called PIIGS but also in other contexts throughout Europe.
Moreover, last week we had in Portugal the largest strike ever, both in the public and private sectors, a strike that took to the streets.
But, if we look at people in the United Kingdom, we see that we witnessed the largest strike ever, particularly if we consider that people also took to the streets as they would in Portugal.
We anticipate a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this demonstrates, Mr. President, and what strikes and people taking to the streets demonstrate, is that the causes and problems we have faced are common, and it is for this reason that the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is spreading to all Member States, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in the financial markets and a growing inability to secure essential financing for our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are healthy, leading to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the rigorous necessity of budgetary discipline, of profound restructurings, of greater economic governance, but these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counteract the ongoing degradation within the Union.

And if it is true, policies are needed that destimulate employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debt. The central issue today is to guarantee the financing of our businesses and our economies, without which the Union will precipitate.
Therefore, more than ever, more than the revision of treaties, we need today a strong and decisive intervention from the European Central Bank.
Eight thank yous, Mr. President, Commissioner, we are here today, all united around a resolution with a very important set of requests in terms of intervention.
We are speaking on World AIDS Day, and this evaluation of the 2009 resolution and communication is fundamental.
It is fundamental precisely regarding things that have already been mentioned.
We repeat because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means there is much to do.

And if we think there are things that cannot get worse, they always can.

One of the points I want to make very clear here concerns the disinvestment that has been occurring in the health sector, and it is a result of the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing.
This setback has severely impacted domains that are fundamental to the fight against HIV/AIDS.
It is for this reason, Commissioner, that I believe the Commission has a fundamental role here in preventing Member States from failing to fulfil their obligations in these areas.

A second issue also relates to the increase in discrimination, as evidenced by the economic and social crisis, discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs because they are carriers of this virus.
That is why prevention, treatment, and care should be equal for all, regardless of sex, age, or the region where they live.
I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner, thank you very much.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr. Drahi.
We are living through special and dramatic circumstances, and they require determined and urgent measures.

The spiral between state debt and bank debt must be broken, but at this moment, the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the countries of the euro zone and the euro itself are not destroyed by rating agencies and speculators.
In the report that we will approve, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the euro area, create eurobonds, and a European treasury, but all of this takes time.
At this moment, we are discussing an emergency, and within this context, the only solution rests with the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Do not be constrained today by inhibitions or limited interpretations of your mandate in your intervention or action.
Your mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At this juncture, there is no room for doubt. Save the euro and do what is necessary – this is what this Parliament and the citizens expect from the European Central Bank.

Budgetary consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.

The tax burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumers, while simultaneously witnessing an entirely disproportionate flight and evasion of taxes.
The group of European Socialists wanted to know how much this leakage and loophole were worth in the 27 EU countries, and they are worth one trillion euros.
This is more than countries in the European Union spend on healthcare.

This signifies a volume so substantial that, were we to allocate only one-fifth of this amount to investment, investment in Europe would rise from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are therefore discussing an exceptionally high value.

The purpose of the resolution we are about to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and the Council to accelerate concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives for fiscal cooperation within the European Union, fiscal cooperation with our neighboring countries, particularly Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country in a bilateral fashion.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and audit.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating fraud and tax evasion across tax jurisdictions.
Europe is not a minor partner.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens, and therefore, my final words in this debate are to encourage the commission and the Council to initiate an effective fight against fraud and tax evasion. Thank you.

Mr. President, I begin by congratulating my colleague on the excellent work and noting the coincidence that, on Europe Day which we celebrate today, we are approving and tomorrow implementing measures that align with the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.

This regulation aims to impose limits on mobile tariffs charged to European consumers when roaming, with its primary objective being to eliminate roaming charges within the European space from 2016 onwards.
Our citizens will now benefit from a significant decrease in prices concerning calls to GSMMS and data.
If today there are operators charging three euros per megabyte, from July onwards, the maximum price they may charge will be 70 cMhos per megabyte, decreasing to 20 cents in 2014.
Regarding incoming calls, the maximum price that can be charged will be eight cents this year and five cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the commissioner stated, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: higher quality information for consumers.
From as early as this summer, operators will be obliged to inform consumers of the rates applied when they also travel outside the European Union.
Until now, the obligation was limited solely to the European space.
Third advantage: the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer may, if they so desire, have two contracts – one for services within the national territory and another for services abroad – maintaining the same mobile phone number and receiving only one invoice.
The consumer, our citizen, will also be granted the possibility of contracting with any European operator that offers them the best price.
This report is the perfect example of Europe of citizens—Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
In February 2009, this Parliament approved a report supporting the European Commission's proposal to revitalize the European economy.

There were projects in clean energy, transportation, new technologies, and innovation, and at that time, the role of the European Investment Bank and the Structural Funds was already being considered.
More than three years later, we were able to produce the Six Pack, the Europa Pa, the budgetary pact, and the TupecEC, all of them replete with reinforced discipline in sanctions.

But, meanwhile, while unemployment, particularly among young people, reaches alarming levels, the European economy enters a recession, and in more than seven of your member states there is negative growth.
Meanwhile, and while Greece is no more than a first stone threatening to topple the castle, the relaunch agenda appears to have been forgotten.
At this moment, that agenda is clear.
What matters at this moment is no longer assigning a character of urgency, but a character of emergency, in a situation that threatens to explode.
It is necessary to intervene urgently in a set of pillars.
First, it is essential that the European Marshall Plan be constituted with investment promoting growth, employment, and convergence.
Project Bonds are one possible source.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates with which countries are financed.
Let us at least prepare to coordinate sovereign debt issuances and to jointly manage the accumulated debt.
Thirdly, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to function, in fact, as genuine firebreaks in the defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was cautiously transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banks must reach businesses.
It is a billion euros held within the banking system, while thousands of viable businesses die every day due to lack of financing.
Fifthly, investment makes no sense without demand.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that must free up domestic demand.

It is that almost all of the exchanges take place within Europe, and it falls to the Commission, Commissioner Ol René, to make recommendations directed not only to the most fragile economies, but also to the most dynamic ones.
And, finally, Mr. President, I conclude by stating the need to limit the revenues and taxes of parastatal entities.

It is necessary to say enough to the punitive style, without dialogue and without accountability, with which senior officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member states. Thank you, President.

to exit this crisis without promoting growth, particularly in those states most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I hear some colleagues, I get the feeling that they think growth can continue with excessive deficits and increased public debt.

of structural reforms. More growth cannot be more relaxation, more respite. More growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand, with great rigor in public finances and with great rigor in structural reforms.
If we only start talking about growth and thinking there are magic growth solutions, we will end up again with unsustainable public debt and will continue without structural reforms.

Having said that, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, in the early morning, it will not only be a question of long-term or medium-term growth at stake. The urgent question of Greece will be at stake, and I believe it is fundamental that European states stand by Greece in some way.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem and wished to repudiate here the assertion of the British Treaty, which spoke of the Portugalization of Europe.

Portugalization of Europe, in terms of flavor and in terms of values, wouldn't be a negative thing. And therefore, it rejects this idea of, ultimately, humiliating or attempting to diminish any people.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. European leaders continue to insist on budgetary discipline, and I ask, budgetary discipline – so let’s examine it. What exactly are we talking about when we speak of budgetary discipline?

In my view, fiscal discipline is respecting the contracts with pensioners and not abandoning state commitments midway. In my view, fiscal discipline is respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cutting subsidies.

The fundamental principle is to respect commitments in health, education, and culture, and to refrain from closing services or terminating and cancelling projects mid-way. Discipline lies in putting banks in order, rather than drawing on taxpayers to hand over funds to speculators in order to save their banks.
This is the budgetary area I would like to see implemented in the European Union and not continue with this market party.

I need an example; the budget being discussed in Portugal by the Troika is a perfect example. I have seen all the commitments that any State should have with its citizens in order not to violate agreements made behind closed doors, agreements that are not uniting Europe and its countries.

I simply wanted to express my gratitude for Mr. Goíses’ spirit of collaboration and to hope that he will take a further step in that spirit, thereby broadening the consensus base surrounding his report, and that this spirit will also prevail with respect to the next one.
It is true, and since it has been pointed out many times, there are many things we do not know about the extraction of grace—this.
But there are also many that we already know and it is advisable not to forget them.

We know, for example, that each xto expenditure extraction operation utilizes over 9 million liters of potable water, which is sufficient to supply a thousand European citizens for a year in terms of their needs.

We also know that for each gas extraction performed in each of the operations, 30 to 300 excuse-piece tonnes—potentially up to 300 tonnes of chemicals—are pumped into the ground, of which approximately two-thirds remain in the soil and do not leave it.

We also know that, with each extraction of gas X, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsurface, which, together with the evaporation of toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute the actual threat to public health.
This is a period of contamination of potable water resources, and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we know that gas extraction from it is also a response that appears easy, focusing only on the immediate, neglecting industry and profit, ignoring populations, the future, and the environment.

But this is also a Europe that understands within this House that water is an essential, vital, and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and must protect it, that seeks agreements to avoid emissions and to promote energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, the environmental standards and those of health.
Therefore, when one does not know everything, being genuine is the minimum.
And they may even want to do it, but do not do it in our name and in the name of citizens whom we represent.
Honorable President, colleagues, in fact, the past years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union did not withstand the crisis.
We have also shown that we have a European institutional architecture full of burqas, particularly the institutional architecture of the euro.
And that is why the report presented here and the proposal presented are significantly above in terms of the vision regarding what is proposed by the governments.
But also, as the drafter said, we are on ground where political choices must be made, and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and cannot support this report.
The first pertains to issues related to conditionalities.

What we see and continue to see is a narrative in which solidarity between different countries can only exist when everything has been fulfilled in terms of the stability and growth plan, in terms of the intergovernmental agreement, the pact for
more than one set of measures that do not impose anything other than massive doses of austerity in the peripheries and also a set of reactive measures that, as we have already seen, are not working.
The second reason relates to banking union.

The report very well presents the mechanism of banking supervision, but it is so necessary that we cannot evade the essential, and the essential here is slipping away to the extent that we continue to summarize.

aggregated national systems, which means we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separate when something goes wrong and, therefore, taxpayers will continue to pay.
A third note concerns the issue of common debt and the issuance of eurobonds.
You must, once again, consider this possibility of common life, but only when it is already too late.

Because we need debt as it currently exists, it’s not solely when deficits and excessive debt have been rectified; because, with the policies we are following, they will never be rectified, quite the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of an entire population.

Therefore, I wish to conclude, Mr. President, by stating that, despite all the hardships, I believe we have here a very clear example of how, united, we could still rise, but divided, we will surely fall. And that was why it was important to have gone even further.
Mrs. Ferreira, please, there are always margins for progress, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union has been fundamental in recent years.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor into a country of highly trained, highly sophisticated labor.
But when a country exports, it is necessary to have conditions for where.
That is why it is important that some countries with surpluses opened their doors to the re-exported goods of countries that departed from a specialization profile that was utterly unsustainable.

A final note to state that it is not possible for immigration to be the solution, that the requalified workforce, where the support of the European Union was utilized, should now be lost through a massive export of the most qualified to countries that have the capacity to receive them.
This is dramatic and completely undermines our future. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Presiding Council, Commissioner, I will be very brief, because I believe that what is at issue here is essentially a political point, is it not?
A financial point, and the question that arises is this: do we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis, or do we want to exacerbate the crisis?
Most European countries are currently making an enormous effort from a public finance perspective to overcome the crisis in a competitive manner, in a way that can position their countries.

The European Union operates on a global scale with considerable competitive and competitive capacity, but it is evident that without investment, there can be no growth, and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, the implication is that the countries doing a tremendous

Those who do not make an effort will not be able to grow, and will pay for this plan that we have deemed acceptable in all countries by the European Union, with sound accounts and prospects for growth and competitiveness.

The sole and principal instrument for this is precisely this multi-annual financial framework, and therefore, if we want the European Union to succeed and this policy to be an exemplary one for other countries, we must invest in the budget for the financial perspectives.
